results.title: Tom Olsson's Cohuna
results.brief_description: Cohuna - When Cohuna Higher Elementary School wanted to raise money for a film projector in 1952, local resident Tom Olsson decided to help by filming life in the township and surrounding countryside, and then showing the footage in the local Town Hall. His footage has been lovingly compiled by the Cohuna Historical Society and the resulting film give us a special glimpse into rural life in 1950’s Victoria. The school recieved their projector, and Olsson’s films were shown annually as a Christmas treat for many years afterward.

results.title: This little pig went to market
results.brief_description: In 1912, Dandy Hams and Bacon commenced at premises located in Dandenong, Melbourne. This short film is a rare record of Dandenong’s first major industry and features reminiscences by Maurie Jarvis (filmmaker Sue Jarvis’s father) who worked at Dandy from the age of 15 until he retired, first as a truck driver and then as a Sales Manager. Now aged 86 Maurie remembers quite fondly of his time at the Dandy Bacon Factory and talks about its operations and processes to a background of rare archival images of the factory buildings, its machinery and its workers. Sadly none of these buildings now exist.

results.title: Stack
results.brief_description: In ‘Stack’, sound artist Ros Bandt captures sounds from the city stack emissions, a 55 metre chimney stack that extracts fumes from the Citylink tunnel. Sounds from the cylinder, the external grid and internal resonant surfaces, along with ambient sounds of the industrial extractor fans and builders working were recorded. Sections of the steel frame were electrified in order to generate original percussion timbres. The tunnel footage was shot and edited by Martin Wright.

results.title: reLOCATED - The Venny kids
results.brief_description: reLOCATED was a community arts project documenting the lives of residents from the Kensington Public Housing Estate who were relocated when the estate was redeveloped. Bailey and Costi’s photography, writing and audio recordings have been combined into short video works especially for the MAP project that allow us to observe instances of beauty in city life while also celebrating the multiple forms of community and history to be found in Melbourne’s inner-West. The Venny was the local playground for kids from the estate, and ‘The Venny Kids’ pays tribute to a place that has seen many happy times.

results.title: Prism of purpose
results.brief_description: Gabo Island - Artist Alexandra Lyall’s paintings of the Gabo Island lighthouse provide haunting visuals to her moving account of the role the lighthouse played in a tragic family history.This work uses digital technology cleverly to allow you to experience Alexandra’s paintings in a new way.

results.title: The Posidon Rush - Jack Flett
results.brief_description: In 1906 there was a brief gold rush to central Victoria following the discovery of the Poseidon Nuggets - the largest of which was 953 oz, on Melbourne Cup day. The rush was named for the winning horse that year. In this short interview Jack Flett recalls the schoolboy excitement of that time and of holding one of the famous nuggets.

results.title: First job after leaving school (c.1916)
results.brief_description: Interviewee Nin Martin from Goldsborough (near Dunolly) talks about his first job as a young lad in 1916 working for a mining company and how he, along with other young boys, used only a hammer to crush open the stones of quartz mined by the older diggers, in order to find the layer of molybdenum which was needed to strengthen the steel in the making of munitions for the war.

results.title: Eucalyptus oil distillery [excerpt]
results.brief_description: At the end of the war in 1946, Horrie Vernon and his brother set up a eucalyptus oil distillery in the small town of St Arnaud in Victoria. In this excerpt (which is part of a longer sequence) Horrie, who is still working the distillery, talks about how the eucalyptus oil is produced: from the collecting of the leaves, to the boiling of the leaves, the collecting of the steam and allowing it to condense, and finally, to the skimming of the oil off the surface. This process which is still carried out in the same way today. is demonstrated in the film.

results.brief_description: When Cohuna Higher Elementary School wanted to raise money for a film projector, local resident Tom Olsson decided to help by filming life in the township and surrounding countryside, and then showing the footage in the local Town Hall. His footage has been lovingly compiled by the Cohuna Historical Society and the resulting films give us a special glimpse into rural life in 1950’s Victoria. The school recieved their projector, and Olsson’s films were shown annually as a Christmas treat for many years afterward. This segment documents the QEII Coronation parade in 1952.
